newsitem.title: USA: Clinton seen sticking behind strong dlr - US experts.
newsitem.headline: Clinton seen sticking behind strong dlr - US experts.

text.p: President Bill Clinton will not alter his administration's longstanding strong-dollar policy despite new pressure from U.S. manufacturers and a Japanese official's statement that the dollar's recovery against the yen has peaked, currency market experts said on Thursday.
"Traders want to see where the U.S. stands, but I'm not so sure the U.S. wants to send much of a (new) signal," said Mike Malpede, senior foreign exchange analyst at Refco Group Ltd.
Malpede added that a currency tug-of-war with Japan could result if the U.S. does not change its strong-dollar policy.

The dollar slid further Thursday after the head of the largest U.S. manufacturing association said Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin is likely to de-emphasize the strong dollar. Just before noon in New York, dollar/yen hit 111.27, close to a one-month low.

U.S. manufacturers have warned recently that the dollar was approaching levels that made U.S. exports uncompetitive. National Association of Manufactuers President Jerry Jainowski told reporters Thursday he felt Rubin "will be saying less about the value of a strong dollar" but added he does not expect Rubin to start "talking down the dollar."
Analysts in the U.S. interpreted Sakakibara's remarks as an attempt to cap the dollar's rise, but not reverse the G3 strong dollar policy.

"They are trying to temper the move up in dollar/yen and mark/yen. I think U.S. (policymakers) will stay away from it, but it will cause dollar/yen to come down because people were long the dollar," said Mark Gargano, managing director of currency derivatives at First Union Natinal Bank.
"I think (dollar/yen) will range from 113 to 110, maybe 108, as people get out of dollars and out of mark, but I don't look for a fundamental change," he added.

"I've heard rumblings that the U.S. may shift dollar policy after Clinton is reelected. There is some concern, with a 40 percent depreciation of the yen and improvement in the current account starting to stagnate, that U.S. officials may consider that," Malpede said.
Gargano said he thinks U.S. policymakers "don't mind" dollar/yen around 114 to 115, but does not believe they would be comfortable with an exchange rate around 125 yen.
Some analysts said if the Clinton administration stays quiet in response to Sakakibara, that will indirectly signal a wish for the dollar to soften.
